channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: From Taylor Swift tickets to social media bans, here are new 2025 state laws
item.description: It's almost the new year, which means states across the country will enact thousands of new laws from new tax structures to prenatal leave.
item.content:encoded:
It's almost the new year, which means states across the country will enact thousands of new laws from new tax structures to prenatal leave.

(Image credit: Kevin Winter)
item.dc:creator: Clay Masters

item.title: Reporters' notebook: revisiting Afghan refugees starting anew in the U.S.
item.description: NPR reporters revisit Afghans who fled their home country after Taliban's takeover in the summer of 2021.
item.content:encoded:
NPR reporters revisit Afghans who fled their home country after Taliban's takeover in the summer of 2021.

(Image credit: Hokyoung Kim for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: 8 questions for President Biden, if he'd take them
item.description: Here's what NPR's White House correspondents would ask Biden at a press conference as his presidency comes to a close.
item.content:encoded:
Here's what NPR's White House correspondents would ask Biden at a press conference as his presidency comes to a close.

(Image credit: Jim Watson)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: What to know about Finland, Russia's 'shadow fleet' and a severed undersea cable
item.description: Finland says a ship affiliated with Russia's "shadow fleet" is linked to a 60-mile-long anchor drag mark on the seafloor. A power cable in the Baltic Sea was severed last week.
item.content:encoded:
Finland says a ship affiliated with Russia's "shadow fleet" is linked to a 60-mile-long anchor drag mark on the seafloor. A power cable in the Baltic Sea was severed last week.

(Image credit: Jussi Nukari)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman

item.title: Why do we drop a ball on New Year's Eve? The Times Square tradition, explained
item.description: Watching a huge ball descend down a pole in Times Square has been a beloved New Year's Eve tradition for over a century. Here's how the spectacle started and what's changed over the years.
item.content:encoded:
Watching a huge ball descend down a pole in Times Square has been a beloved New Year's Eve tradition for over a century. Here's how the spectacle started and what's changed over the years.

(Image credit: Matty Zimmerman)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Should you be worried about bird strikes during your next flight?
item.description: Bird strikes occur daily for commercial flights, costing airlines millions in damages each year. Although rare, these incidents can result in injuries and fatalities.
item.content:encoded:
Bird strikes occur daily for commercial flights, costing airlines millions in damages each year. Although rare, these incidents can result in injuries and fatalities.

(Image credit: Petros Karadjias/AP)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: Tiger-cats, sea squirts and beetles, oh my! Meet some species identified in 2024
item.description: From charismatic macrofauna to tiny sea squirts, here are some species formally identified by scientists in 2024.
item.content:encoded:
From charismatic macrofauna to tiny sea squirts, here are some species formally identified by scientists in 2024.

(Image credit: Juan Camilo Botero)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Transit systems turn to AI-powered cameras to catch drivers who block bus lanes
item.description: The nation's biggest transit systems are using AI-enhanced cameras to keep bus lanes clear of illegally parked cars. That's making buses move faster, but the rollout has hit a few speed bumps.
item.content:encoded: The nation's biggest transit systems are using AI-enhanced cameras to keep bus lanes clear of illegally parked cars. That's making buses move faster, but the rollout has hit a few speed bumps.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: South Korea to inspect Boeing aircraft as it struggles to find cause of plane crash
item.description: Many worry how effectively the South Korean government will handle the disaster as it grapples with a leadership vacuum after the impeachments of the country's top two officials.
item.content:encoded:
Many worry how effectively the South Korean government will handle the disaster as it grapples with a leadership vacuum after the impeachments of the country's top two officials.

(Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Treasury says Chinese hackers remotely accessed documents in 'major' cyber incident
item.description: The revelation comes as the U.S. grapples with a massive cyberespionage campaign that gave Chinese officials access to private texts and phone conversations of an unknown number of Americans.
item.content:encoded:
The revelation comes as the U.S. grapples with a massive cyberespionage campaign that gave Chinese officials access to private texts and phone conversations of an unknown number of Americans.

(Image credit: Andy Wong)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
